content.question: In Case <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, a ball is held at rest by ropes <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of negligible mass, as shown in the side-view figure. Rope <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is horizontal and attached to a wall, while Rope <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is at an angle and attached to the ceiling. The ropes exert tension forces with magnitudes <math alttext="T sub 1 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math> and <math alttext="T sub 2 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math> on the ball, as indicated. In Case <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, Rope <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is moved, and the tensions in this case are <math alttext="T sub 1 B, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub></math> and <math alttext="T sub 2 B, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly describes the relationship between <math alttext="T sub 1 B, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub></math> and <math alttext="T sub 1 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="T sub 1 B, end sub, equals T sub 1 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math>, because the orientation of Rope <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is the same in both cases.

<math alttext="T sub 1 B, end sub, equals T sub 1 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math>, because the tension in Rope <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is zero in both cases.

<math alttext="T sub 1 B, end sub, is less than T sub 1 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math>, because in Case <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> the vertical component of the tension force of Rope <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is smaller.

<math alttext="T sub 1 B, end sub, is less than T sub 1 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math>, because in Case <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> the horizontal component of the tension force in Rope <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is smaller.

content.answer: <math alttext="T sub 1 B, end sub, is less than T sub 1 A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math>, because in Case <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> the horizontal component of the tension force in Rope <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is smaller.
